CatDescriptText: Elma Proctor, housewife, Third Ward and Edgar Moore, taxi driver, Beltzhoover, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, August 27, 1960, pg. A1 with question "What are the most appealing nad the least appealing aspects of Republican presidential candidate Richard M. Nixon?"  Mrs. Proctor's answer reads: "He's a Republican, and Republicans are not for the poor class.  This is against him.  One good thing which he has is the desire to pass a Civil Rights Bill which I think he would do."  Mr. Moore's answer reads: "His least appealing aspect is the fact that he's a Republican.  I don't think the Republican party is going to do much for the working class.  He's Vice President of the country and that's the most appealing aspect."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Elma Proctor wearing sleeveless patterned dress and woven belt, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Edgar Moore wearing dark People's Cab cap, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
